Based on my web search for "SuperClaude V3", I found comprehensive information about this development framework. Here's what I discovered:

SuperClaude v3 is a framework that extends Claude Code with 16 specialized commands, smart personas, and MCP server integration.(no content)Fresh out of beta with unified CLI installer.

## Key Features

SuperClaude is an open-source framework that extends Claude Code with 19 specialized commands, 9 cognitive personas, and evidence-based development workflows. The framework includes:

- **Specialized Commands**: Development: /sc:implement, /sc:build, /sc:design Analysis: /sc:analyze, /sc:troubleshoot, /sc:explain Quality: /sc:improve, /sc:test, /sc:cleanup Others: /sc:document, /sc:git, /sc:estimate, /sc:task, /sc:index, /sc:load, /sc:spawn

- **Smart AI Personas**: AI specialists that try to jump in when they seem relevant: ðŸ—ï¸ architect - Systems design and architecture stuff

- **MCP Integration**: MCP server integration for docs, UI components, and browser automation

## Installation

SuperClaude v3 also supports installation via uv (a faster, modern Python package manager) or uvx for cross-platform usage.(no content)Compatible with Python 3.8+ and works smoothly with SuperClaude.

Basic installation commands include:
- SuperClaude install # Interactive selection (choose components) SuperClaude install --interactive # Minimal install (just core framework) SuperClaude install --minimal

## Core Philosophy

The most profound of these rules is the principle of Evidence-Based Operation. In a world where AI can "hallucinate" answers, SuperClaude enforces a CRITICAL rule against making unsubstantiated claims.(no content)Before implementing any code involving an external library, SuperClaude is required to use C7 to look up the official documentation. This "Research-First" policy is non-negotiable.

## Changes from V2

Key Change: /build is now /sc:implement for feature implementation Â· Migration: Replace v2 /build myFeature with v3 /sc:implement myFeature

## Status and Privacy

The basic stuff works pretty well, but definitely expect some rough edges since it's a fresh release.(no content)SuperClaude runs 100% locally with no third-party servers or data collection. It's open source and MIT licensed.

The framework is available on GitHub, PyPI, and has its own documentation website, showing it's an actively developed open-source project focused on enhancing Claude Code's development capabilities.

========================================================================

========================================================================


AppWizard has created this FidesGUI_Std_Utility DLL for you.  This DLL not only
demonstrates the basics of using the Microsoft Foundation classes but
is also a starting point for writing your DLL.

This file contains a summary of what you will find in each of the files that
make up your FidesGUI_Std_Utility DLL.

FidesGUI_Std_Utility.dsp

    is used to build a single project or subproject. Other users can share the
    project (.dsp) file, but they should export the makefiles locally.

    This is a listing of all of the Microsoft Windows resources that the

	Visual C++.

    such as the name and description of the DLL.  It also exports

    These files are used to build a precompiled header (PCH) file

#### ì‚¬ìš©ìž ì •ì˜ ì„±ëŠ¥ ì¹´ìš´í„° ì¶”ê°€
```cpp
// ì• í”Œë¦¬ì¼€ì´ì…˜ ì„±ëŠ¥ ì¹´ìš´í„° êµ¬í˜„
class CPerformanceCounter
{
private:
    HQUERY m_query;
    HCOUNTER m_counter;
    
public:
    bool Initialize(const wchar_t* counter_path)
    {
        if(PdhOpenQuery(NULL, 0, &m_query) != ERROR_SUCCESS) {
            return false;
        }
        
        if(PdhAddCounter(m_query, counter_path, 0, &m_counter) != ERROR_SUCCESS) {
            return false;
        }
        
        return true;
    }
    
    double GetValue()
    {
        PDH_FMT_COUNTERVALUE counter_value;
        
        PdhCollectQueryData(m_query);
        
        if(PdhGetFormattedCounterValue(m_counter, PDH_FMT_DOUBLE, 
                                      NULL, &counter_value) == ERROR_SUCCESS) {
            return counter_value.doubleValue;
        }
        
        return -1.0;
    }
};

// ì‚¬ìš© ì˜ˆì‹œ
void MonitorSystemPerformance()
{
    CPerformanceCounter cpu_counter;
    CPerformanceCounter memory_counter;
    
    cpu_counter.Initialize(L"\\Processor(_Total)\\% Processor Time");
    memory_counter.Initialize(L"\\Memory\\Available MBytes");
    
    while(true) {
        double cpu_usage = cpu_counter.GetValue();
        double available_memory = memory_counter.GetValue();
        
        LOG_MESSAGE("CPU: %.1f%%, Available Memory: %.0f MB", 
                   cpu_usage, available_memory);
        
        Sleep(5000);  // 5ì´ˆë§ˆë‹¤ ì²´í¬
    }
}
```

### 4.2 ë¡œê·¸ ë¶„ì„ ë„êµ¬ ì„¤ì •

```cpp
// ì• í”Œë¦¬ì¼€ì´ì…˜ ì„±ëŠ¥ ì¹´ìš´í„° êµ¬í˜„
class CPerformanceCounter
{
private:
    HQUERY m_query;
    HCOUNTER m_counter;
    
public:
    bool Initialize(const wchar_t* counter_path)
    {
        if(PdhOpenQuery(NULL, 0, &m_query) != ERROR_SUCCESS) {
            return false;
        }
        
        if(PdhAddCounter(m_query, counter_path, 0, &m_counter) != ERROR_SUCCESS) {
            return false;
        }
        
        return true;
    }
    
    double GetValue()
    {
        PDH_FMT_COUNTERVALUE counter_value;
        
        PdhCollectQueryData(m_query);
        
        if(PdhGetFormattedCounterValue(m_counter, PDH_FMT_DOUBLE, 
                                      NULL, &counter_value) == ERROR_SUCCESS) {
            return counter_value.doubleValue;
        }
        
        return -1.0;
    }
};

// ì‚¬ìš© ì˜ˆì‹œ
void MonitorSystemPerformance()
{
    CPerformanceCounter cpu_counter;
    CPerformanceCounter memory_counter;
    
    cpu_counter.Initialize(L"\\Processor(_Total)\\% Processor Time");
    memory_counter.Initialize(L"\\Memory\\Available MBytes");
    
    while(true) {
        double cpu_usage = cpu_counter.GetValue();
        double available_memory = memory_counter.GetValue();
        
        LOG_MESSAGE("CPU: %.1f%%, Available Memory: %.0f MB", 
                   cpu_usage, available_memory);
        
        Sleep(5000);  // 5ì´ˆë§ˆë‹¤ ì²´í¬
    }
}
```

message.content:
This session is being continued from a previous conversation that ran out of context. The conversation is summarized below:
Analysis:
Let me chronologically analyze this conversation to understand the user's requests and my actions:

1. **Initial Request**: User asked "í°í‹€ë¡œ ì •ë¦¬í•´ì¤€ê²ƒì€ ìž˜ë´¤ì–´ í°í‹€ì˜ ë‚´ìš©ì„ ìƒì„¸í•˜ê²Œ ë‚˜ëˆ ì„œ ì‹ ìž…ì‚¬ì›ì´ ì´í•´í• ìˆ˜ìžˆëŠ” ìžë£Œë¥¼ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ì¤˜" - They wanted me to take the high-level overview I had previously provided about the MINESOTA project and create detailed educational materials that new employees could understand.

2. **My Approach**: I created a comprehensive 8-part educational guide series for new employees, using TodoWrite to track my progress through 5 main tasks:
   - Basic concept explanation
   - System-specific detailed guides (CTC/TMC/PMC/GUI)
   - Practical examples and tutorials
   - Development environment setup guide
   - FAQ and troubleshooting guide

3. **SuperClaude Inquiry**: User asked about "SuperClaude V3" - they wanted to know what it was, and then requested installation.

4. **SuperClaude Installation**: I successfully installed SuperClaude V3 (version 3.0.0.1) using pip, though there were some encoding issues with the interactive installer that I worked around.

5. **MINESOTA Analysis Request**: User asked me to analyze and document all code in the D:\MINESOTA directory. I performed comprehensive analysis of the project structure, identifying it as a semiconductor equipment automation system with CTC/TMC/PMC/GUI components.

6. **Educational Material Creation**: I created 8 detailed markdown files for new employee training, covering everything from basic concepts to advanced troubleshooting.

7. **Task Master MCP Inquiry**: User asked if I knew about Task Master MCP, which I explained in detail.

8. **Task Master Availability**: User asked if I could use Task Master ("task master ì‚¬ìš© ê°€ëŠ¥í•´?"), and I explained I couldn't access it but could use TodoWrite instead.

9. **Simple "1" Response**: User just typed "1" - I asked for clarification about what they meant.

10. **MCP Table Reference**: User shared the MCP server comparison table I had created earlier.

11. **MCP Setup Request**: User asked "ë‚´PCì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©í• ìˆ˜ìžˆê²Œ MCP ì„¤ì •í•´ì¤˜" - they wanted me to set up MCP servers on their PC for use with Claude Desktop.

12. **Current Work**: I was in the process of setting up MCP servers on their Windows PC. I had:
    - Verified Claude Desktop installation
    - Confirmed Node.js availability
    - Attempted to install MCP servers (some failed due to package name changes)
    - Successfully installed core MCP servers: @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem, @modelcontextprotocol/server-memory, @modelcontextprotocol/server-sequential-thinking
    - Found existing Claude Desktop config file with many MCP servers already configured
    - Was about to modify the configuration to add the newly installed servers

Key technical details include specific npm package installations, file paths, and Claude Desktop configuration structure.

Summary:
1. Primary Request and Intent:
   - Initial request to create detailed educational materials for new employees based on a high-level MINESOTA project overview
   - Request to install and explain SuperClaude V3
   - Request to analyze and document all code in D:\MINESOTA directory  
   - Request to set up MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers on user's Windows PC for use with Claude Desktop

2. Key Technical Concepts:
   - MINESOTA semiconductor equipment automation system (CTC/TMC/PMC/GUI architecture)
